title: 109_s2205
content: The Act titled "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006" is referred to as the short title. It pertains to the conveyance of land related to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. In this section, "Blunt Reservoir feature" refers to a component of the Oahe Unit, James Division, part of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. "Commission" means the Commission of Schools and Public Lands of the State. "Nonpreferential lease parcel" is a land parcel acquired by the Secretary for use with the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The Pierre Canal feature is part of the Oahe Unit, James Division, under the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. A nonpreferential lease parcel is a land parcel associated with the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. A "leaseholder" is a person or descendant who held a lease on a preferential lease parcel related to the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features as of January 1, 2001. A "preferential lease parcel" is land purchased by the Secretary for use in connection with these features and designated as such on the Bureau of Reclamation's 2001 lease roster. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and an unleased parcel is defined as land not under lease purchased for the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and the State may accept liability for the ownership, operation, and maintenance of certain features. The State may accept liability for outstanding obligations associated with expired easements or rights granted in, on, over, or across certain features. The Commission will act as the agent for the Secretary in administering the purchase option for preferential leaseholders. Outstanding obligations described shall benefit the State. Oil, gas, mineral, and other rights conveyed to the State will be binding. The conveyance to the State or sale to a preferential leaseholder shall be subject to reserved oil, gas, and mineral rights, as well as any outstanding permits or leases on the property. The conveyance to the State or sale to a preferential leaseholder shall be subject to reserved oil, gas, and mineral rights, as well as any outstanding permits or leases on the property. A preferential leaseholder has the option to purchase the preferential lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission. A preferential leaseholder may elect to purchase a parcel on cash terms equal to a specified amount. The value of the parcel for a preferential leaseholder to purchase is determined under paragraph (4) minus ten percent of that value. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the parcel through an installment plan with 10 percent down and the rest paid over 30 years at 3 percent interest. If the parcel is under $10,000, it must be purchased in cash. The leaseholder has 5 years to exercise the purchase option. The preferential leaseholder has the option to purchase the parcel through an installment plan with 10 percent down and the rest paid over 30 years at 3 percent interest. They can continue to lease the parcel under the same terms until a specified date. The value of the lease parcel is determined by an independent appraisal less 25 percent. The Fair Market Value of a property under the preferential leaseholder agreement must be resolved in accordance with federal regulations. If the leaseholder fails to purchase the parcel within the specified period, the Secretary will offer to convey the parcel to the state. The Secretary will offer to convey a parcel to the State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Proceeds from land sales will be deposited as miscellaneous funds in the Treasury for the establishment of a trust fund to pay county taxes. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Land conveyed will be used for this purpose, and proceeds from land sales will establish a trust fund to pay county taxes. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will use land for wildlife habitat mitigation lost due to the Pick-Sloan project. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands may allow land exchanges for nonpreferential lease parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal with their concurrence. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will use land for wildlife habitat mitigation lost due to the Pick-Sloan project. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands may allow land exchanges for nonpreferential lease parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal with their concurrence. Priority is given to exchanges with current lessees and adjoining landowners for unleased parcels and nonpreferential lease parcels. The United States reserves a perpetual easement for water conveyance structure in the exchange of land at the Pierre Canal feature. The United States reserves a perpetual easement for a water conveyance structure over the Pierre Canal feature. The United States will not be held liable for damages arising from any act, omission, or occurrence related to the conveyed parcel, except for acts of negligence committed by the United States. The United States is not liable for damages related to the conveyed parcel, except for acts of negligence committed before the date of conveyance. This section does not add to any liability under the Federal Tort Claims Act. During the interim period, the Secretary will continue to lease preferential and nonpreferential lease parcels. The Secretary will provide parcel descriptions of preferential and nonpreferential lease parcels to the State within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the Secretary will transfer archeological collections to the State without cost. The Secretary will transfer archeological and cultural items from the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features to the South Dakota State Historical Society at no cost. $750,000 is authorized for implementing the Act, with additional funds to reimburse expenses incurred by the Commission and State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks, not exceeding 10% of transaction costs.
